race.name: Flint Hills Death Ride
race.tagline: Kansas Flint Hills gravel in Cottonwood Falls.

climate.description: Variable conditions with heat and wind possible.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through rolling Flint Hills prairie. Significant elevation with prairie scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional KS event. Flint Hills terrain is nice but moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Flint Hills Death Ride is a regional event in Cottonwood Falls, Kansas—rolling Flint Hills prairie with significant elevation. The Flint Hills scenery is unique, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Cottonwood Falls provides moderate access. Spring/fall weather brings heat and wind challenges.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Kansas gravel race with Flint Hills prairie terrain. Worth it for Kansas cyclists seeking a local prairie event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Kansas Flint Hills gravel in Cottonwood Falls.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Kansas and want a local Flint Hills event—yes, it's a solid regional race. If you're from out of state—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better events: Unbound. For similar regional events: Switchgrass, other KS gravel races.

logistics.airport: Wichita (ICT) 1.5 hours or Kansas City (MCI) 2 hours
logistics.lodging_strategy: Cottonwood Falls has limited lodging. Emporia has more options.
logistics.food: Small town with limited dining. Stock nutrition.

course_description.character: Rolling Flint Hills prairie gravel with significant climbing.
course_description.signature_challenge: Flint Hills prairie gravel in central Kansas.

non_negotiables.why: Flint Hills rolling prairie requires sustained effort (4500 feet).
KS spring/fall means heat and wind are likely.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Kansas Flint Hills gravel in Cottonwood Falls.

logistics.explanation: Burnsey describes organizational chaos: 'The finish line was non existent and a total let down; no cameras, no cheers, no cowbells...nothing. I had to ask around town just to see where I was to go and if I needed to check in somewhere.' The race died amid jersey fulfillment scandals, with riders like Redneck Biker unable to get refunds from organizer Paul Corcoran after paying $80.

length.explanation: Course distance varied by year from 62 miles to 85 miles, with most sources citing 70-80 miles through Kansas gravel. Even severely under-geared riders like Burnsey finished successfully, spinning 'like a gerbil on cocaine' at 12 mph on his single speed 29er but still completing the route by 3 PM. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar. As Motocraftsman puts it: "Fun Fact, The Death Ride began in Matfield Green, KS. John Hobbs would scare the s**t out of you before you even started. I don't remember much about encouraging words, or finish line hugs."

technicality.explanation: Burnsey confirms 'the 80+ miles of dirt was nothing more than a gravel road ride' on Kansas ranch roads. A local woman successfully rode multiple events on 'a litespeed titanium road bike,' demonstrating the course's road bike compatibility despite the intimidating marketing. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 2003 modified route featured 'over 6,000 feet of climbing' according to race organizer J.C. Van Deventer, with other years citing 5,000 feet of gain. The rolling Flint Hills prairie creates consistent climbing through old ghost towns, oil fields, and cow pastures rather than massive peak ascents. Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 69°F and lows of 46°F, with a 39% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 29 mph. The 2003 race continued despite 'tremendous rains' that flooded Interstate 35 and killed seven people, forcing riders through 'forty-foot river crossings where the water had completely submerged the bridge.' Typical years brought 'dehydration, sunburns' in Kansas heat with no prairie shelter from wind or sun. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Cottonwood Falls sits around 1,200 feet in the Kansas Flint Hills with no altitude impact on performance. Any breathing difficulties come from Kansas dust and relentless prairie wind, not thin air. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The route traveled through 'old deserted ghost towns, oil fields, and cow pastures' on historic stagecoach roads. Elite rider Darin Slack found the experience transformative: 'The Death Ride changed me. It was a very sobering and maturing ride that challenged my emotions probably more than my muscles.'

prestige.explanation: Founder John Hobbs claimed 'at least 60% of the riders wouldn't finish,' but elite rider Burnsey calls 'bullshit on that one' since his entire group completed it. The race was historically significant as one of gravel racing's pioneers alongside Trans Iowa, influencing the creation of Dirty Kanza.

race_quality.explanation: Elite rider Bill Stephenson called it 'the hardest thing I've ever done. Give me back my easy 12 hour mountain bike races.' However, organizational execution was poor - Burnsey rated it '1 out of 5' for race management, praising only that 'all of the volunteers at the SAG stations were super nice and helpful.'

experience.explanation: Despite organizational failures, the Flint Hills terrain delivered memorable suffering. In 2003's extreme weather, only 31 riders finished the flooded course 'better suited for boats and ducks than mountain bikes,' with final finishers completing just before 7 PM after over 10 hours of racing.

community.explanation: Race founder John Hobbs 'would scare the s**t out of you before you even started' with intimidation over encouragement. The original race spawned the UNDEAD Death Ride successor, where organizers donate '100% of gross profit to entities in Madison and Matfield Green' at $20 entry fees.

field_depth.explanation: At its peak, the race 'saw over 400 riders take part in it' before organizational collapse. The 2003 extreme weather year saw significant attrition with 'only 31 riders made it to the finish line' after the flooded river crossing and deteriorating conditions eliminated many participants. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Original entry fees reached $80 but came with fulfillment problems and poor execution. The modern UNDEAD successor offers the same Flint Hills terrain experience for $20 with transparent community donation policies, making authentic prairie gravel accessible at budget pricing.

expenses.explanation: Redneck Biker paid $80 but never received his jersey despite months of contact attempts with organizer Paul Corcoran. Rural Kansas around Madison and Matfield Green offers reasonable lodging and food costs, with the current UNDEAD event charging just $20 entry fees. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
